pageData.text: Nuclear (radioactive) decay is the process by which an unstable atomic nucleus loses energy by emitting radiation. Students will investigate different nuclear decay mechanisms to learn how one element transmutes into another and will simulate nuclear decay, record and graph their data, and observe the nature of <button class='glossary-text'>exponential decay</button>.

pageData.text: Much of today’s security technology relies on random sequences of numbers to act as encryption and keep online data and devices secure. However, generating a sequence of numbers that is truly random is very challenging. Most systems rely on mathematical formulas that generate sequences that are close to random, but actually have an identifiable pattern to other computers. This makes them susceptible to hacking, making the system vulnerable. In order to generate a truly random number, you must use a completely random process to provide the entropy, or disorder, to generate the random sequence. There are few truly random processes in the universe; radioactive decay, however, is thought to be one of them.  Although the <button class='glossary-text'>half-life</button> of a radioactive <button class='glossary-text'>isotope</button> can be calculated, it is impossible to predict, with current technology, exactly which atom in a group will decay next and exactly when the decay will take place. Scientists can create a True Random Number Generator (TRNG) by using a small amount of radioactive material hooked up to a detector and a computer system<sup>1</sup>. As the atoms in the material randomly decay, a location on the detector is activated generating a number on the computer system that corresponds to that specific location.  Because the decay is unpredictable, the sequence is also impossible to predict, creating a secure encryption.

1Park, K., Park, S., Choi, B. G., Kang, T., Kim, J., Kim, Y. H., & Jin, H. Z. (2020). A lightweight true random number generator using for IOT Applications. ETRI Journal, 42(6), 951–964.
https://doi.org/10.4218/etrij.2020-0119

pageData.desc: A sequence of numbers that appears to be random.
pageData.altText: A sequence of numbers that appears to be random.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Radioactivity</button> has been applied in numerous fields for over 100 years. First discovered by the French scientist Henri Becquerel, radioactive sources are used in medicine, to sterilize food, and to generate power. Radioactive materials can also be used to calculate the dates of certain artifacts. The application of radioactive sources depends on a knowledge of how the radioactive decay process works.

In 1896, Becquerel was experimenting with uranium samples by exposing them to sunlight before placing them on photographic plates. The uranium exposed the plate to create an image of the sample, which Becquerel believed was due to sunlight that had been absorbed by the uranium. However, an image of the sample was also produced when Becquerel left a piece of uranium in a closed drawer next to a photographic plate. Therefore, this experiment proved that there was an unseen source of radiation emanating from the uranium samples.

Other scientists who contributed to radioactivity studies include Marie Curie, Pierre Curie, and Ernest Rutherford. Early experiments placed radioactive sources in a magnetic field and demonstrated that the radiation from the uranium samples was not like the previously discovered X-rays, which were detected as a result of high-energy electron beams produced during experiments with discharge tubes. Instead, the radiation from sources like uranium was a result of the nuclear decay process.

The nucleus of an atom is composed of positively charged <button class='glossary-text'>protons</button> and neutral <button class='glossary-text'>neutrons</button>. The positive particles repel each other due to the electromagnetic force. Neutrons have no charge and are neither attracted to nor repelled by the electromagnetic force. The particles in a nucleus are held together by what is known as the <button class='glossary-text'>strong force</button>. As the name implies, this is a force much stronger than the electromagnetic force but is only effective at very short distances. When protons are very close together, the strong force holds them together to overcome the electromagnetic force that pushes them apart. Larger atoms have more protons and neutrons, and the protons are farther apart. Neutrons help stabilize the nucleus by contributing to the strong force without adding to the repulsive electromagnetic force.

The nuclei of some atoms are unstable. These nuclei spontaneously break down and emit radiation in the process. Radioactivity is the emission of charged particles as unstable atomic nuclei spontaneously decay. During the process of , radioactive containing unstable nuclei spontaneously change into other isotopes, meaning that the atoms of one element change into those of another element. This happens as charged particles are emitted from the atom as nuclear radiation. Early experiments in radioactivity determined that there are three types of radiation: , , and .

pageData.subTitle: Alpha Decay
pageData.text: When a nucleus is so large that the electromagnetic repulsion between is significantly greater than the , the nucleus is unstable and emits an . An alpha particle consists of two protons and two , which is the same composition as a helium nucleus. The symbol for an alpha particle in standard nuclear notation is: 42 He

The upper number (4) is the mass number representing the total number of protons and neutrons. The lower number (2) is the atomic number representing the total number of protons. The symbol He represents the element helium.
The following nuclear equation describes the nuclear decay of polonium-210: 21084 Po → 42 He + 20682 Pb

In this reaction, polonium-210 undergoes alpha decay, emitting an alpha particle and transmuting into lead-206, which has an atomic number 82 compared to 84 for polonium (see Figure 1). In a decay process, the original element is called the parent nucleus and the element present after the reaction is called the daughter nucleus. In the nuclear decay of polonium-210, polonium is the parent nucleus and lead is the daughter nucleus.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Nuclear equation for the nuclear decay of polonium-210
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Nuclear equation for the nuclear decay of polonium-210

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Alpha radiation</button> is the least penetrating type of nuclear radiation. A few centimeters of air, a sheet of paper, or clothing is enough to stop an alpha particle.

pageData.subTitle: Beta Decay
pageData.text: Another process that may transform an unstable atom into a more stable one is beta decay. This form of decay may be beta positive (β+) or beta negative (β-). In both processes, the total number of nuclear particles remains constant; however, the atomic number will either increase or decrease. In β- decay, the number of in the nucleus increases by one as a decays into a proton. During the decay process, a beta particle (an electron) is emitted from the nucleus. Because an electron has very little mass compared with a proton or neutron, it is assigned a mass number of 0. The symbol for a beta particle is: 0-1 e
The following equation shows the beta decay of iodine-131: 13154 l → 0-1 e + 13154 Xe

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Atomic particles demonstrating the equation for beta decay of iodine-131
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Atomic particles demonstrating the equation for beta decay of iodine-131

pageData.text: The daughter <button class='glossary-text'>isotope</button>, xenon-131, has one more proton than the parent isotope, iodine-131, but the mass number remains the same (see Figure 2).

During β+ decay, the daughter products are a (a particle with the mass of an electron and a positive charge) and a daughter nucleus with an atomic number one fewer than the parent nucleus. Essentially, a proton becomes a neutron. 106 C → 0+1 e + 105 B

Elements that undergo beta decay have useful applications in the medical field. Radiotherapy is a type of cancer treatment that uses beta decay. Radioactive atoms, such as yttrium-90, are ingested and release the beta particles into the body, killing nearby cancer cells.

pageData.subTitle: Gamma Decay
pageData.text: Unlike and decay, gamma decay does not involve the emission of charged particles. A ray, the most penetrating of the three types of nuclear radiation, has no mass or charge. A nucleus undergoing gamma decay emits gamma ray photons (see Figure 3).

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Slow neutron interaction with a nuclide
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Slow neutron interaction with a nuclide

pageData.question: Radioactive decay of an unstable isotope into another isotope is considered which of the following?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: During the process of transmutation, atoms of one element change into those of another element as charged particles are emitted from the atom as nuclear radiation.

pageData.question: Which of the following statements about radioactive decay is true?

options.text: The atomic mass of an isotope does not change after beta decay.
Alpha particles are most like electrons.
Gamma radiation is the last penetrating type of nuclear radiation.
A father nucleus decays into a daughter nucleus during transmutation.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: During beta decay, the daughter products are a beta particle and a daughter nucleus with an atomic number one greater or fewer than the parent nucleus, but the mass number remains the same. A beta particle can be positive (positron) or negative (electron) but either way has very little mass compared with a proton or neutron; therefore, it is assigned a mass number of 0.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: During the process of transmutation, radioactive isotopes containing unstable nuclei spontaneously change into other isotopes, meaning that the atoms of one element change into those of another element. This happens as charged particles are emitted from the atom as nuclear radiation. Early experiments in radioactivity determined that there are three types of radiation: alpha, beta, and gamma. When polonium-210 undergoes alpha decay, it emits an alpha particle and transmutes into lead-206, which has an atomic number of 82 compared to 84 for polonium. In a decay process, the original element is called the parent nucleus, and the element present after the reaction is called the daughter nucleus. Alpha radiation is the least penetrating type of nuclear radiation. A few centimeters of air, a sheet of paper, or clothing is enough to stop an alpha particle. During beta decay, the daughter products are a beta particle and a daughter nucleus with an atomic number one greater or fewer than the parent nucleus. Radiotherapy is a type of cancer treatment that uses beta decay. Radioactive atoms, such as yttrium-90, are ingested and release the beta particles into the body, killing nearby cancer cells. A gamma ray, the most penetrating of the three types of nuclear radiation, has no mass or charge. A nucleus undergoing gamma decay emits gamma ray photons.

img.alt: Figure 1: Nuclear equation for the nuclear decay of polonium-210

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: During the process of transmutation, radioactive isotopes containing unstable nuclei spontaneously change into other isotopes, meaning that the atoms of one element change into those of another element. This happens as charged particles are emitted from the atom as nuclear radiation. Early experiments in radioactivity determined that there are three types of radiation: alpha, beta, and gamma. When polonium-210 undergoes alpha decay, it emits an alpha particle and transmutes into lead-206, which has an atomic number of 82 compared to 84 for polonium. In a decay process, the original element is called the parent nucleus, and the element present after the reaction is called the daughter nucleus. Alpha radiation is the least penetrating type of nuclear radiation. A few centimeters of air, a sheet of paper, or clothing is enough to stop an alpha particle. During beta decay, the daughter products are a beta particle and a daughter nucleus with an atomic number one greater or fewer than the parent nucleus. Radiotherapy is a type of cancer treatment that uses beta decay. Radioactive atoms, such as yttrium-90, are ingested and release the beta particles into the body, killing nearby cancer cells. A gamma ray, the most penetrating of the three types of nuclear radiation, has no mass or charge. A nucleus undergoing gamma decay emits gamma ray photons.

img.alt: Figure 1: Nuclear equation for the nuclear decay of polonium-210

pageData.subTitle: Half-Life
pageData.text: Although the process of nuclear decay is random for a given element, the overall rate of decay is constant. A radioactive element is often described in terms of its , which is the time it takes for half of the atoms in the radioactive sample to undergo nuclear decay. The carbon-14 has a half-life of 5,730 years. If a carbon sample contained 100 grams of carbon-14, in 5,730 years there would be 50 grams of carbon-14 remaining. In 11,460 years (twice the half-life), there would be only 25 grams. Carbon-14 undergoes beta decay and transmutes into nitrogen-14. 146 C → 0-1 e + 147 N

pageData.subTitle: Radioactive Dating
pageData.text: can be measured to determine the age of some objects; this is known as . In living matter, such as plants and animals, this can be accomplished by examining the ratio of carbon isotopes. (For example, scientists used carbon dating to determine that bristlecone pine trees in Nevada and California are approximately 10,000 years old.) The ratio of carbon-12 to carbon-14 isotopes in the environment is relatively constant. Plants and other organisms absorb or ingest carbon atoms from the environment, and these are incorporated into molecules during different biological processes. As long as the plant or animal is alive, the ratio of carbon isotopes in the organism is the same as it is in the environment. When an organism dies, it ceases to bring in carbon from the environment. Therefore, the carbon isotope ratio changes as carbon-14 decays into nitrogen-14, while the stable carbon-12 isotopes remain unchanged.
Radioactive dating uses the half-life equation in Equation 1, where mf is the final mass, m0 is the initial mass, t is the time elapsed, and h is the half-life.

pageData.desc: Equation 1: m sub f equals m sub o times 1/2 raised to t over h
pageData.altText: Equation 1: m sub f equals m sub o times 1/2 raised to t over h

pageData.text: The ratio of carbon-14 to carbon-12 in the remains of a deceased organism can provide information about how much time has passed since the organism died. For inorganic materials like rocks, other isotopes can be used for radioactive dating.

pageData.question: The ratio of carbon-14 to carbon-12 in the remains of a deceased organism can provide information about how much time has passed since the organism died. What does carbon-14 transmute into?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Carbon-14 undergoes beta decay and transmutes into nitrogen-14.

pageData.question: Which of the following is used in radioactive dating to determine the age of a sample?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Radioactive dating is a method of dating geological or archeological specimens by determining the relative proportions of radioactive isotopes present in a sample.

Plants and other organisms absorb or ingest carbon atoms from the environment, and these are incorporated into molecules during different biological processes. As long as the plant or animal is alive, the ratio of carbon isotopes in the organism is the same as it is in the environment. When an organism dies, it ceases to bring in carbon from the environment. 146 C → 0-1 e + 147 N

In activity 1, you will pour out the pennies, then count the number of heads and tails. Then, you will return the pennies showing heads to the container. Until 1 penny remains in the container, repeat this process. Finally, you will graph the data.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: How do neutrons help to stabilize the nucleus?

options.text: They add to the strong nuclear force without adding any repulsive electromagnetic force.
They add to both the strong nuclear force and the repulsive electromagnetic force.
They add to the repulsive electromagnetic force without adding any strong nuclear force.
They reduce the strong nuclear force and add to the repulsive electromagnetic force.
They reduce both the strong nuclear force and the repulsive electromagnetic force.

assestmentData.question: Which type of decay is represented below? 23994 Pu → 23592 U+ 42 He
A scientist is observing radioactive decay and observes 2312 Mg decay into 2311 Na. What type of decay does this represent?
You observe an atom undergoing gamma decay. What particle would you expect to be emitted from the nucleus of the atom?
Which of the following is NOT true about radioactive dating using carbon isotopes?

options.text: Carbon-14 decay into nitrogen-14 is an example of alpha decay.
The ratio of carbon-12 to carbon-14 in the environment is relatively constant.
The half-life of carbon-14 is 5,730 years.
When an organism dies, it ceases to take in new carbon from the environment.
When an organism dies, the carbon-14 begins to decay into nitrogen-14 while the amount of carbon-12 stays the same.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is an application of radioactivity?
You start with 100 g of a radioactive substance. After 20 minutes, there is only 12.5 g left. How many half-lives took place in 20 minutes?
Which of the following items will you need to supply yourself to complete this investigation?

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Collect 100 pennies (or other coins).
Place the pennies in the plastic beaker (or foam cup).

In Activity 1, you will model <button class='glossary-text'>exponential decay</button> using pennies as atoms, flipping the coins to simulate random decay processes. You will then graph the percent of parent pennies versus number of half-lives.

typeBefore.text: Note: This activity simulates the process of nuclear decay. The pennies represent atoms. Pennies that turn up heads represent the radioactive atoms; pennies that turn up tails represent atoms that have undergone nuclear decay. Assume that all 100 pennies start out as heads. This is half-life “0” as shown in Data Table 1.

pageData.text: Pour all the pennies onto a level surface.
Sort the pennies that turned up tails from those that turned up heads.
Count the number of pennies that turned up heads, and record this number in Data Table 1 in the row for “1.” These are the parent pennies. Record the percent of parent pennies in Data Table 1.
Count the number of pennies that turned up tails, and record this number in Data Table 1. These are the daughter pennies. Record the percent of daughter pennies in Data Table 1.
Place only the parent pennies (that turned up heads) back in the beaker. The total number of parent and daughter pennies will always remain the same (as shown in Data Table 1).
Shake the beaker gently to randomize the pennies, and pour them onto the level surface.
Repeat Steps 2–6 until a single penny remains.
Graph the data on graph paper, or use a graphing calculator or spreadsheet to graph the data.

text: The number of half-lives is represented on the x-axis.
The percent of parent pennies is represented on the y-axis.
The curve through the data points is an example of <button class='glossary-text'>exponential decay</button>.
The ratio of the radioactive isotope (heads) to the daughter product (tails) indicates how many half-lives have occurred.
Put the materials back in the materials kit, and gather the pennies.
Clean your work area.

text: The three types of radiation were identified in part by their reactions to an electromagnetic field.  Based on the information in the background section, how could a magnetic field be used to separate alpha, beta, and gamma radiation?

Radon is a naturally occurring, colorless, odorless, tasteless radioactive gas.  Radon can build up in closed spaces like mines or buildings, and both radon and its decay products can be serious health hazards to people living and working where it has accumulated.  Radon-224 undergoes alpha decay.  What daughter nucleus is produced?
Uranium-238 undergoes alpha decay.  Into what element does Uranium-238 transmute?  What is the atomic number of the new element?
Technetium-99m is a radioactive isotope with a half-life of 6 hours.  If a sample was 100 mg, how much would remain after 24 hours?
How long would it take a 1-kg radioactive substance with a half-life of 100 years to decay into 125 g?

data.title: Alpha particle
data.content: A particle that consists of two protons and two neutrons, which is the same composition as a helium nucleus

data.title: Alpha radiation
data.content: A type of nuclear radiation in which an alpha particle is emitted

data.title: Beta radiation
data.content: A type of nuclear radiation in which a beta particle (either an electron or positron) is emitted

data.title: Exponential decay
data.content: The process of a quantity decreasing over time, with the rate of decrease becoming proportionally smaller as the quantity gets smaller

data.title: Gamma radiation
data.content: A type of nuclear radiation in which gamma ray photons are emitted

data.title: Half-life
data.content: The time it takes for half of the atoms in the radioactive sample to undergo nuclear decay

data.title: Isotope
data.content: One of two or more types of atoms that have the same atomic number and position in the periodic table, and that differ in nucleon numbers due to different numbers of neutrons in their nuclei

data.title: Neutron
data.content: A particle found in the nucleus of an atom that has no charge and is neither attracted to nor repelled by the electromagnetic force

data.title: Positron
data.content: A particle with the mass of an electron and a positive charge

data.title: Proton
data.content: A positive particle found in the nucleus of an atom

data.title: Radioactive dating
data.content: A method of dating geological or archeological specimens by determining the relative proportions of particular radioactive isotopes present in a sample

data.title: Radioactivity
data.content: The emission of ionizing radiation or particles caused by the spontaneous disintegration of atomic nuclei

data.title: Strong force
data.content: A force much stronger than the electromagnetic force but is only effective at very short distances; it holds particles in the nucleus together

data.title: Transmutation
data.content: When referring to nuclear transmutation, it is a process that involves a change in the nucleus of an atom
